brief_metadata.target_audience: Marketing, HR, Finance, Sales professionals, Executives, Team Leads, Directors, Managers

module_overview.description: Develop an agile mindset by exploring growth mindset, mental models, complexity, and polarities. Run the Team Alignment Canvas activity to align teams around purpose and ways of working.
module_objectives: Develop a growth mindset and recognize blind spots and mental models
Understand complexity and how to manage polarities effectively
Align teams around shared purpose, values, and ways of working using the Team Alignment Canvas
module_overview.key_activity: Team Alignment Canvas - hands-on team alignment exercise

learning_objectives: Describe the attributes of a growth mindset in contrast to the limitations of a fixed mindset
Introduce the concept of reframing failure as an opportunity to learn
Apply growth mindset principles to business challenges

key_points: Growth mindset vs fixed mindset - talents and abilities can be developed (from learning outcomes)
Resilience and thriving in uncertainty require growth mindset
Failure as learning opportunity - essential for experimentation and innovation
Growth mindset as foundation for business agility

definitions.Growth Mindset: The belief that talents and abilities are not static, but can be developed and improved through effort and learning (source: learning outcomes, Carol Dweck research)
definitions.Fixed Mindset: The belief that talents and abilities are innate and unchangeable, limiting openness to challenges and learning
definitions.Resilience: The ability to recover from setbacks and adapt to changing circumstances

concepts_to_explain: Why growth mindset is paramount for Business Agility (learning outcomes context)
The relationship between mindset and psychological safety
How to reframe failure in enterprise business contexts (marketing campaigns, HR initiatives, finance projects)
The role of mindset in embracing change and uncertainty

needed: Marketing example: Failed campaign as learning opportunity
HR example: Recruitment strategy that didn't work leading to innovation
Finance example: Budget forecasting miss as chance to improve models
Executive example: Strategic pivot based on learnings from setback
Growth mindset self-assessment tool or exercise
Real-world stories of growth mindset in action in enterprise settings
from_learning_outcomes: Contrast growth vs fixed mindset in Business Agility context

teaching_guidance.approach: Start with self-reflection, then provide framework, then apply to business contexts
engagement_methods: Small group discussion on past 'failures' and learnings
Pair sharing on growth mindset challenges in their organizations
common_misconceptions: Growth mindset means everything is easy with enough effort
Fixed mindset is bad or shameful (it's a default we all have)
Growth mindset eliminates failure (it reframes it as learning)
visual_suggestions: Growth vs Fixed mindset comparison chart

research_needs: Carol Dweck's research on growth mindset - key findings and practical applications
Growth mindset examples in enterprise business contexts (non-IT)
Self-assessment tools or exercises suitable for business audience
Statistics on correlation between growth mindset and organizational performance
How to create psychological safety to support growth mindset

sections.section_title: Mental Models, Blind Spots, and Sense Making
learning_objectives: Recognize that blind spots and mental biases exist and understand their role
Apply the skills needed to examine mental models and how individuals make meaning
Identify personal mental models that may constrain agility

key_points: Mental models shape our perceptions and beliefs (from learning outcomes)
Everyone has blind spots - recognizing them is first step
Change agents must identify their own patterns before helping others
Slowing down thinking to generate awareness
Forming and reinforcing new mental models

definitions.Mental Models: Internal representations of how we think the world works, filtered from experiences, beliefs and values (source: learning outcomes)
definitions.Blind Spots: Areas where our mental models prevent us from seeing reality accurately
definitions.Sense Making: The process by which individuals make meaning from experiences and information
definitions.Cognitive Biases: Systematic patterns of deviation from rationality in judgment

concepts_to_explain: How mental models are formed from experiences, beliefs, and values
Why traditional management models may no longer serve us
How to slow down thinking processes to generate awareness
Techniques for examining and updating mental models
The role of mental models in resistance to change

needed: Enterprise business examples of limiting mental models
Marketing: 'Traditional advertising is the only way to reach customers'
HR: 'Annual performance reviews are essential for accountability'
Finance: 'We must have detailed 3-year budgets'
Sales: 'Face-to-face meetings close more deals'
Mental model mapping exercise template
Case study of organization that successfully challenged mental models
from_learning_outcomes: Patterns of behavior filtered from experiences
Reframing mental models to address business needs

teaching_guidance.approach: Create safe space for vulnerability, use interactive exercises to surface mental models, provide frameworks for examination
engagement_methods: Mental model mapping exercise (individual then share)
Small group discussion: 'What mental models drive your decisions?'
Ladder of Inference exercise to show how we form conclusions
common_misconceptions: Only others have blind spots, not me
visual_suggestions: Mental model iceberg (visible behavior vs underlying beliefs)
Before/after examples of reframed mental models

research_needs: Common mental models in business and enterprise settings
Ladder of Inference framework (Peter Senge)
Practical exercises for identifying mental models
Common cognitive biases relevant to business decision-making
Techniques for updating mental models (cognitive reframing)
Case studies of mental model shifts in organizations

learning_objectives: Provide an overview of complex adaptive systems and complexity theory
Provide practical awareness of relevant management models (Cynefin, Theory of Constraints, Systems Dynamics)
Distinguish between complicated and complex contexts

key_points: Organizations are complex adaptive systems (from learning outcomes)
Traditional management models may constrain effectiveness in complexity
Understanding complexity accelerates path to Business Agility
Different contexts require different approaches (Cynefin framework)

definitions.Complex Adaptive Systems: Systems where many independent agents interact in unpredictable ways, with emergent properties (source: learning outcomes)
definitions.Complicated: Many parts but predictable - experts can diagnose and solve
definitions.Complex: Unpredictable, emergent - requires experimentation and adaptation
definitions.Emergence: Properties or behaviors that arise from interactions, not predictable from individual components

concepts_to_explain: Difference between complicated and complex problems
Cynefin framework: Clear, Complicated, Complex, Chaotic, Confused domains
Theory of Constraints (Eli Goldratt) - identifying bottlenecks
Systems Dynamics (Peter Senge) - feedback loops and delays
Why detailed planning doesn't work in complex environments

needed: Business examples for each Cynefin domain
Marketing: Campaign performance in complex social media landscape
HR: Organizational culture change as complex challenge
Finance: Market dynamics and economic forecasting
Simple visual of Cynefin framework
Interactive exercise to classify problems as complicated vs complex
Enterprise case study applying complexity thinking
from_learning_outcomes: Management models: Cynefin (Dave Snowden), Theory of Constraints (Eli Goldratt), Systems Dynamics (Peter Senge, Jay Forrester)

teaching_guidance.approach: Start with relatable examples, introduce frameworks visually, practice classification, emphasize implications for how we work
engagement_methods: Pair discussion: Identify complex challenges in your work
Group activity: Map a business problem through Cynefin lens
common_misconceptions: Complex problems can be solved with detailed plans
Complexity theory is too academic for practical use
visual_suggestions: Cynefin framework diagram with enterprise examples
Feedback loop diagram for systems thinking

research_needs: Cynefin framework - Dave Snowden's work, practical applications
Enterprise business examples for each Cynefin domain
Theory of Constraints - Eli Goldratt summary for business professionals
Systems Dynamics basics - Peter Senge's Fifth Discipline key concepts
Simple exercises for distinguishing complicated vs complex
How complexity thinking changes leadership approaches

learning_objectives: Distinguish polarities (dilemmas, paradoxes) from traditional problems
Learn to see the relationship between poles to optimize wins and minimize losses

key_points: Many recurring business problems are unsolvable - they're polarities (from learning outcomes)
Polarities require ongoing management, not one-time solutions
Optimizing the upsides and minimizing downsides of both poles

definitions.Polarity: An interdependent pair of values or viewpoints that seem to be opposites but are actually both necessary (source: learning outcomes, Barry Johnson)
definitions.Paradox: A seemingly contradictory statement that when investigated may prove to be true
definitions.Dilemma: A situation requiring choice between equally undesirable alternatives
definitions.Both/And Thinking: Ability to hold two seemingly contradictory ideas as both valid

concepts_to_explain: Why some problems can't be 'solved' - they're ongoing tensions
Classic business polarities (stability vs change, individual vs team, short-term vs long-term)
Polarity Management framework basics
How to identify whether something is a problem (solvable) or polarity (manageable)
The infinity loop of polarities
Benefits of both/and mindset for collaboration

needed: Enterprise business polarity examples
Marketing: Brand consistency vs innovation
HR: Employee autonomy vs organizational alignment
Finance: Cost control vs investment in growth
Sales: Relationship building vs transaction efficiency
Polarity map template and example
Exercise: Identify polarities in participants' work
Case study of successful polarity management
from_learning_outcomes: Unsolvable problems require management not solution

teaching_guidance.approach: Start with familiar either/or dilemmas, introduce polarity concept, practice mapping, emphasize this is ongoing management not one-time fix
engagement_methods: Small group: Identify a polarity from your organization
Pair share: Both/and vs either/or examples
common_misconceptions: All problems can and should be solved
Both/and thinking means wishy-washy lack of decision
One pole is right and the other is wrong
visual_suggestions: Polarity map template (4 quadrants showing upsides and downsides)

research_needs: Polarity Management by Barry Johnson - key concepts and framework
Enterprise business polarity examples across functions
Polarity map template with instructions
Common organizational polarities
Both/and mindset research and benefits
How to facilitate polarity mapping exercise

learning_objectives: Facilitate team alignment around shared purpose and values
Create clarity on roles, responsibilities, and ways of working
Establish team norms and expectations collaboratively

key_points_from_video: 5-section canvas: Goals (team), Individual Goals, Roles & Skills, Values, Roles & Activities (operational), Purpose (from video 0:30)
Tool designed to ensure right team assembled before innovation process (video 0:38)
Main reason teams fail: wrong team or wrong motivations (video 1:45)
Purpose emerges after filling out other sections (video 3:52)
Can identify missing skills, duplicate skills, need for team changes (video 4:01)

canvas_sections.Individual Goals: Personal learning objectives for each team member (video 1:15-1:42)
canvas_sections.Roles & Skills: Individual contributions - unique value each person brings (video 1:55-2:15)
canvas_sections.Values: Core values and guiding principles underpinning work (video 2:18-2:47)
canvas_sections.Roles & Activities: Day-to-day operations, knowledge transfer, communication methods (video 2:51-3:17)
canvas_sections.Purpose: Higher purpose beyond just another project (video 3:29-3:55)

core_content.timing_and_context: Use at kick-off after scoping, before diving into project (video 3:20)

needed: Team Alignment Canvas template (physical and digital versions)
Enterprise business examples for each canvas section
Marketing team example: Goals, values, purpose
HR team example: Individual goals, skills needed
Finance team example: Operational activities, knowledge transfer
Facilitation guide for running the exercise
Time allocation for each section of canvas
Debrief questions after completing canvas
What to do with insights (next steps)

teaching_guidance.approach_from_video: Progressive building through sections, purpose emerges at end, use for self-reflection and team optimization
facilitation_flow: Team Goals - work together to define (5 min)
Individual Goals - silent reflection then share (5 min)
Roles & Skills - individual then collective view (5 min)
supplies_needed: Large canvas template on flip chart or wall
Digital tool option (Miro, Mural) for virtual teams
key_facilitation_points: Emphasize psychological safety - honest answers needed
Purpose should emerge naturally, not forced
Identify skills gaps and duplicates without judgment
Focus on team optimization, may need to change members
Link back to growth mindset, mental models, and values work from earlier
common_misconceptions: This is just a feel-good exercise (video warns teams fail without alignment)
We already know all this (video shows surprises emerge)
Purpose is the starting point (it actually emerges at end)
visual_suggestions: Photos of teams working on canvas

research_needs: Team Alignment Canvas - official template source (Board of Innovation)
Downloadable templates (PDF, Miro, Mural)
Detailed facilitation guide for 30-minute session
Enterprise team examples for each canvas section
Best practices for virtual vs in-person facilitation
